ContentClassification.TableReference: Chas H. Wickens, Commonwealth Statistician and Actuary, “Census of the Commonwealth of Australia 1921, Part XXVII Life Tables”, Government Printer (Camberra,1929). Accessed: February, 2014 from http://www.ausstats.abs.gov.au/ausstats/free.nsf/0/6AC5A5E862763860CA2578390017D9D6/$File/1921%20Census%20-%20Volume%20II%20-%20Part%20XXVII%20Life%20Tables.pdf AND http://www.ausstats.abs.gov.au/ausstats/free.nsf/0/13A21D5C84E44BFACA25783900180D8A/$File/1921%20Census%20-%20Volume%20II%20-%20Statisticians%20Report.pdf
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Australian Life Tables 1920-22 Male. Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 104
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Tables are based on the population results of the census of April 4, 1921, and the death registrations for the three years 1920, 1921, and 1922. Owing to the abnormal experience of the decennium 1911-1920 due to the War of 1914-1918, and to the influenza epidemic of 1919, it was considered advisable to compile the present tables on the basis of the three years 1920, 1921, and 1922, rather than on that of the decennium 1911-1920. The smallness of the numbers involved and the uncertainty of the statements made for very advanced ages, renders it impossible to closely investigate this period of life, but the evidence obtainable appears to place 105 as the maximum age attainable. Methodology: The initial rate obtained in the tables compiled in connection with the Census 1911 (See SOA Table Identities 60013 and 60029) was what is technically known as “force of mortality”. This method was adopted for the 1921 tables. For lives under age 5, the method employed is identical to that detailed in “The Census of the Commonwealth of Australia, 1911” and in the Transactions of the Australasian Association for the Advancement of Science, Vol. XIV in a paper entitled “Investigations Concerning a Law of Infantile Mortality”. For ages above 5, q(x) were derived from l(x) where l(x) derived from L(x) through use of the formula l(x) = [ 7 * (L(x-1) + L(x)) – (L(x-2) + L(x+1)) ] / 12. Though smooth within themselves, the juvenile ages did not necessarily join smoothly to the results obtained for ages 5 and upwards. To rectify this junction as well as to eliminate occasional irregularities in the more advanced ages, parts of the table of q(x) were plotted and then a smooth curve drawn through the results. Smoothed rates were then compared to actual and where this comparison indicated excessive or defective rates a rectification was made arithmetically and the smoothed curve being maintained by adjusting the differences of the successive terms. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 02/2014

MetaData.TableDescription: Australian Life Tables 1920-22 Male. Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 104
